Your Home Security

Burglaries are often carried out by opportunist thieves who take their chances on properties which look like an easy target.

36% of burglaries take place through unlocked doors and windows, so keeping your property locked and secure is essential to prevent opportunist thieves.

Take a look at your home through a burglar’s eyes. Check your windows, do they lock? Are you able to ventilate them securely? If you think your security looks poor, chances are, so does a burglar.

Window locks and warning stickers can easily be seen from the outside and put thieves off as they know they will have to break the glass to enter, which risks attracting attention. Window locks and simple security measures will help to make your home less attractive to thieves, will last a long time and help add value to your home.

How Can We Help?

We know how to help increase overall safety and security, to combat and to help reduce crime.

Window Security Direct is a sister company of Solon Security, who has over 18 years’ experience providing crime prevention and community safety items solely to the police, councils and local government and have developed products and solutions over time that really do work.

A burglary can be a very upsetting experience, and can leave a home owner feeling vulnerable and anxious.

Keeping your home locked and secure can help reduce the fear and risk of crime for you and your family.

Have a look at our security tips, advice and essential window security items to help ensure your home is as secure as can be.

How important is door and window security?

Very important. In most cases, the offenders who commit burglary are opportunists. They see an open door or window and they take their chance. Believe it or not but nearly half of all burglaries are committed through an open door or window. A third of burglaries occur through a rear window. An open window or door is therefore an open invitation to enter your home. No other aspect of crime prevention is more effective than improving your door and window security. Keep them closed and locked especially when you are not in that room.

What can I do to improve the security of my existing windows?

Fit key operated locks to as many of your windows as possible especially if they are downstairs, hidden from view or easily accessible upstairs e.g. above a flat roofed porch. Consider having security film installed on such windows. Don't forget to remove keys from window locks and store them in a safe place.

West Midlands Police

Window Security
(PAS 011)

Product Approval Specification 011: 1994 has been developed by the BSI to assess the security performance of domestic windows. PAS 011 tests the whole system, including hinges and latches, but not the glass.

PAS 011 is not a full British Standard, but one that is added to existing product quality kitemarks, e.g. BS 7412 - PAS 011 (PVC) or BS 644 - PAS 011 (Timber). You should never see PAS 011 on its own. It must always be accompanied by the kitemark and appropriate BS number.

Window Locks

In the absence of a multi-point locking system and laminated glass, all ground floor windows and those which open onto accessible areas, balconies or roofs should be fitted with window locks, unless designated as a means of escape.

Other devices are available to fit on PVCu windows and doors to improve their security. However, specialist advice should be sought as to the choice of fixings, otherwise the improvement may be negligible, or worse still, make the unit less secure.

French Windows

These generally open outwards have exposed hinges and at least two flexible edges. These doors are especially susceptible to attack from levering instruments, e.g. screwdrivers, jemmies or even garden tools.

Security on timber and metal frame French windows can be improved by fitting mortise or surface-mounted security bolts on the inside top and bottom, together with hinge bolts and frame reinforcement.

 

 

Louvre Windows

Louvre window slats should be glued into the end plates to prevent easy removal. Where possible replace with fixed glass panels.

Keys to all window locks, French windows and patio doors must be hidden from view, but kept nearby in case you need to get out of your home in the event of a fire or other emergency. Check with your insurer or landlord to find out if they are required.

Glass

For those windows and other glazed areas which are at higher risk of criminal attack, fit Laminated Safety Glass. It improves security and offers a safer environment inside the home. Vulnerable areas include patio doors, French windows and glazed external doors, as well as windows adjacent to any door.

Beware of toughened safety glass! It shatters into thousands of small pieces with no sharp edges, leaving a gaping hole to climb or reach through: toughened safety glass can be regarded as 'burglar friendly'. Do not confuse it with laminated safety glass.

In double glazed units, laminated glass on both the inner and outer surfaces will offer the ultimate protection. However, one pane of laminated glass should be enough to prevent entry. It is generally recommended that the laminated pane is fitted on the inside surface, thereby offering protection from the burglar and reduced risk of accidental injury to the occupants.

NB. For laminated glass to be most effective, it should be installed in frames that are also capable of resisting criminal attack, e.g. conforming to PAS 011:1994. West Midlands Police recommend that laminated glass (6.4mm minimum thickness), is used in all ground floor windows, as well as those at other accessible locations, i.e. above side garages, over porches, extensions, etc. 

Metropolitan Police

Windows are often used as either an entry or exit route for burglars. Properties with windows left open or unsecured locks are a desired target for the opportunist burglar. 

Tips

- Remember to close and lock all your windows, even if you are only going out for a few minutes.

- Windows on the ground floor and in accessible areas should be made of toughened glass or doubled glazed.

- Make sure windows are fitted with a good lock appropriate for the window type.

- Avoid leaving valuables, house or car keys near windows.

Are you insured?

Saving money by not taking out home insurance is not worth the saving. Unfortunately almost half of all burglary victims are uninsured. Without insurance you will have to find the money to replace what is stolen or damaged. Insurance will cover possessions stolen from your home and your insurer will cover the cost of replacements. The average contents premium is only around £130 per year and a number of insurers now offer cover aimed at social tenants which is even cheaper – about £1 per week. Ask your social landlord if they belong to a low cost tenants’ insurance scheme.

What level of home security do insurers require?

Insurers recommend that locks and alarms are fitted in customers’ homes and that these should meet certain standards. In high-risk areas they will insist that customers fit good quality door and window locks and burglar alarms. Insurers often use information on how secure a property is when they are deciding whether to offer cover, on what terms and conditions, and what premium to charge. Improving the security on your home can help make sure you get the best possible deal from the insurance market when you buy or renew your cover.

Good security measures complement your insurance cover by giving you peace of mind, knowing your home is well protected. However, some things are irreplaceable; for example, your engagement or wedding ring, special jewellery or family photographs have sentimental value which cannot be measured. It is therefore important to do all you can to prevent your home being burgled in the first place.

Advice from an insurance company

Home Office Top Tips

The Home Office has prepared some common sense top tips to help prevent you from becoming a victim of burglary. These are:

1. Fit strong locks to external doors and windows, and make sure they are locked at all times.

2. Always remove all keys from inside locks, and keep them out of sight and in a safe place.

3. Fit sturdy deadlocks (British Standard BS3621) to all doors.

4. Make sure your doors and frames are strong and in good condition - wood doors should be at least 44mm thick.

5. Mark your property - having it marked helps police verify it's been stolen.

6. Fit a door chain or bar and door viewer (spy-hole), and use them.

7. Never leave a spare key in a convenient hiding place such as under the doormat, in a flowerpot or behind a loose brick - thieves know to look there first.

8. When you are out in the evening, leave your lights on and shut the curtains.

9. Install outside security lighting; if other people can see your property a burglar may think twice.

10. Keep your tools and ladders securely locked up – a burglar could use them to get into your house.

A guide to Home Security

A third of burglars get in through a window.

If you are replacing windows, take the opportunity to install new ones that are certified to British Standard BS7950 ‘Windows of Enhanced Security’ and consider using laminated glass, particularly in ground-floor and accessible windows, as this is much harder to break.

Otherwise, window locks that can easily be seen from outside may put some thieves off, because the thief would have to break the glass and risk attracting attention. And even if they do break the window, they still can’t open it so risk cutting themselves climbing through the broken glass.

Home security and DIY shops sell inexpensive, key-operated locks to fit most kinds of windows. You may need more than one window lock, depending on the size of the opening you need to secure.

Fit window locks with keys to all downstairs windows and windows that are easy to reach – for example, those above a flat roof or near a drainpipe.

Even small windows such as skylights or bathroom fanlights need locks. A thief can get through any gap that is larger than a human head.

Remember to keep windows locked. Remove the keys and keep them out of sight in a safe place.

Louvre windows are especially vulnerable because thieves can easily take the slats out of the frame. Glue the slats into place, and fit a special louvre lock. Better still, replace them with fixed glass.

The Home Office also publishes ‘A guide to Home Security’ which provides useful advice on how to make your home more secure.

Top Everyday Home Security Tips

1. Don't leave any spare keys under the doormat or even in your greenhouse or shed, consider installing a hidden key safe.

2. Always keep garden sheds and garages locked and think about using a portable shed alarm or padlock alarm.

3. It is essential that all ground floor and easily accessible windows should be secured key operated locks.

4. Lock all doors and windows when you leave the house, even if you'll only be out for a short time.

5. Window locks can help prevent burglars from gaining access, especially in older windows and windows without double glazing.

6. If you are considering buying PVC or metal framed doors/windows, ask about having built in locks and a fitted chain, as these can be difficult to install afterwards.

7. A letterbox is one of the most vulnerable areas in your house. Consider using an external mailbox or a locking letterbox. Ensure all keys including car keys are out of sight and kept in a secure place.

8. Remove keys from window and door locks and keep them in a safe place where everyone in the house can easily access them in case of fire.

9. As soon as it begins to turn dark, draw your curtains.

10. Lock, Stop, Chain, Check. Keep the door locked, even when at home. Stop & think if anyone is expected, look through a door viewer to identify a caller. Always put the door chain or bar on first before opening the door. Ask to check the callers I.D even if the caller has a pre-arranged appointment. Refuse if you are unsure. Don't be a victim to doorstep burglars.

Useful Advice

Consider using loose gravel around your home, it creates a lot of noise and may help to alert you someone is approaching the house. It may also help to deter an opportunist burglar who doesn't want to be heard.

Use dusk - dawn lighting which comes on automatically during the night to help deter thieves.

Install a visible burglar alarm and use stickers and signs to make sure an opportunist thief knows your home is protected.

Don't leave valuable items on display within the home, especially if they are within reach through the letterbox. A thief can use a pole or a stick to reach in and fish items out from a surprisingly far distance.

Keep your house secure while you’re away

If you are planning on going away, consider asking a friend or neighbour to drop by in the evening to draw the main curtains in the house and pick up any mail.

Use 24 hour segment timers for mains operated items such as lamps and radios if you will be out of the house overnight or on holiday. They create the impression that someone is at home. It is not recommended to use TVs for this purpose however you could consider using a FakeTV which can be used with a timer.

Make sure all of your windows and doors are locked, with the key removed.

Did you know Did you know?

58% of burglaries take place in the evening or night and 34% occur at the weekend.

A third of all burglars gain access through a rear window or door.

Every minute, 365 days a year a dwelling is broken into. Don’t make it easy for them, as an opportunist thief is always looking for the next easy picking.

Burglars don’t like to be seen, for that reason most burglaries take place during the afternoon or evening when your home is empty. They also target empty homes or properties that are easily accessible.

Two thirds of all burglaries are through windows.

It does work – In recent research it is proven that 200,000 burglaries are prevented each year because of good security locks and alarms.

Avon and Somerset Police > Burglary Prevention

Thames Valley Police > Summer Time Burglary

Secured By Design > Burglary Prevention Advice

Cambridgeshire Police > Beat the Burglar

Take a look at the Met Police essential home security tips on youtube.

Security News

1 November 2013, Daily Mail

November, the month you're most likely to be burgled: House is broken into every two minutes.

A home is burgled every two minutes in November making the month the worst of the year for break-ins. Police data obtained by a freedom of information request reveals that one in ten domestic burglaries take place in November and that a break-in takes place every two minutes. 

15th November 2011, West Mercia Police

Window locks thwart burglars at Broseley Pub

Extra locks on windows prevented burglars breaking into a Broseley pub. The would-be burglars used a ladder found at neighbouring premises to climb onto a roof at The Ironmaster in the High Street. They smashed a window but were unable to gain entry because of extra locks which had been fitted.

17th January 2013, Enfield Independent

Thief stole laptop from house by climbing though open ground floor window, caught by police.

A burglar climbed through an open ground floor window and snatched a laptop, he was then caught just minutes after by the police who saw him running off with the cable trailing behind him, he has been jailed for four years.

Myth from Fact

Myth: They’ll get in if they want to, no matter what I do!

Fact: Most burglaries are committed by opportunist thieves who are soon discouraged by properties which show signs of security, alarms and good locks. Look at your home through a burglars eyes and secure the weakest point first, then work your way up to make your home look less attractive to thieves. 

Myth: It’s OK, I have house insurance.

Fact: Loss of possessions or cash does not compensate for the emotional feelings of vulnerability, or the sentimental value of a wedding ring or engraved jewellery which cannot easily be compensated for by money alone. Can your insurance alone buy you peace of mind?

Some Interesting Facts

Did you know that burglary is the most preventable of crimes? Simply make your home the least burglar attractive and most burglar proof in your neighborhood.

Recent research shows that at least 200,000 burglaries per year are prevented because people have taken the trouble to fit security locks and systems to their homes.

How to Lock a Window

A general guide to locking windows and keeping them secure is to make sure all ground floor windows or easily accessible windows are secured with locks which have removable keys. The locks can be anything which secured the window to its frame with a strong bolt or jammer. Take a look at our range of window locks.

Product Details

The ERA 720-25 Window Restrictor is designed to restrict window opening to 75mm, and is able to be locked either in a closed or partially closed position with a removable key. The restrictor allows ventilation whilst ensuring your home is both safe for children and secure from risk of break-in. Ideal for homes, schools, hotels or high rise office buildings.

Features

  • Removable key
  • Allows ventilation
  • Manufactured from high tensile aluminium
  • Designed with child safety in mind
  • Restricts window opening to 75mm
  • Brown Finish
  • Suitable for wooden windows
  • Trade packed with all fixings and instructions
